section.title: Introduction
section.para: This is a text file written in Org-mode (http://www.orgmode.org), and it is used as a test case for my Org-to-DocBook exporter. Each section contains some feature in Org-mode...

section.title: About Sections and Subsections
section.para: DocBook supports numbered sections and also recursive sections. We choose recursive sections (element <section>) in DocBook exporter to make generated DocBook documents much more portable. Sections can be freely moved to different places, either in an article or in a book, at different levels.

As Org files tend to contain a lot of headings, which are transformed to empty sections in DocBook. Empty paragraphs, like <para></para>, are added for such sections to make generated XML document valid.

section.title: About Images
section.para: Here is an image with caption and label:

In Org-mode, an image file can be used as the description of a link, and the image is exported as a click-able image in HTML export. In DocBook format, the image file path is formatted as it is. See the following link: /Users/bcui/Org/docbook-cover.png

section.title: About Timestamps, TODOs, and Tags
section.para: This is a timestamp <2009-03-02 Mon>.
For TODOs, we can simply put the TODO keywords in [...] to make them stand out in section titles. For tags, they are formatted as superscript. We may need to find other better-looking formats.

section.title: About Footnotes
section.para:
Please see my first footnote.
Body of first footnote. And here is the second one.
Body of second footnote.
Check the first footnote again.

Here is a long footnote.
This is the body of the third footnote, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long, and it is long.... Stop here!

This is a LaTeX-like anonymous footnote.
This is the inline definition of this anonymous footnote.

This is another footnote with inline definition and a name.
This is the definition of second inline footnote, which has a name.
Here I am referring to the previous named footnote.

section.title: About Links
section.para: This is an http link: CNN Web Site.
This is another one: http://www.cnn.com.
FTP link: One Gnu FTP Link.
FTP link: ftp://ftp.gnu.org/path/to/something.
File link: file:~/.emacs::45.
File link: file:~/Org/test0.org.
Check the first footnote for the third time.

section.title: Regular Tables
section.para: If a table has a caption, then it will be formatted as a regular table in DocBook using element <table>. Here is an example table that has a caption "My Phone Book":

section.title: Informal Tables
section.para: Tables without a caption will be formatted as informal tables in DocBook using element <informaltable>. Such tables do not have a caption. See this example:

section.title: About Verses and Quotes
section.para: If the source of a verse or quote (a.k.a. attribution in DocBook) is found in the verse or quote, an <attribution> element will be added to element <blockquote>. This helps format verses or quotes more nicely.

section.title: Verses
section.para: The following is a verse with attribution ("-- AlexSchroeder", which appears in the last line in the verse):

blockquote.literallayout: Great clouds overhead Tiny black birds rise and fall Snow covers Emacs

section.para: The next one is a verse without attribution:

blockquote.literallayout: O, for a muse of fire, that would ascend The brightest heaven of invention! A kingdom for a stage, princes to act, And monarchs to behold the swelling scene!

section.title: Block Quotes
section.para: This is a block quote with attribution ("-- Albert Einstein", which appears in the last line of the quote).

blockquote.para: Everything should be made as simple as possible, but not any simpler.

section.para: Here is one block quote that has two paragraphs but no attribution:

blockquote.para: God does not care about our mathematical difficulties. He integrates empirically.

Great spirits have always found violent opposition from mediocrities. The latter cannot understand it when a man does not thoughtlessly submit to hereditary prejudices but honestly and courageously uses his intelligence.

section.title: About Literal Examples
section.para: You can include literal examples that should not be subjected to markup. Such examples will be typeset in monospace, so this is well suited for source code and similar examples.
section.programlisting:
Some example from a text file. This can include characters like '<' and '>', etc.
The following line should not be regarded as the continuation of a long footnote: \par This is NOT part of a footnote.
section.para: For simplicity when using small examples, you can also start the example lines with a colon followed by a space. There may also be additional whitespace before the colon:
Here is an example:

section.title: About Drawers
section.para: Drawers are something that people normally do not want to see. So they should not appear in the DocBook output. This is just to confirm that.

section.title: This is a headline
section.para: Still outside the drawer. After the drawer.

section.title: About Typesetting
section.para: This is underlined, and emphasize, and verbatim, and italic text, and verbatim text.

section.title: Itemized Lists
section.para: This is paragraph one. This is paragraph one. This is paragraph one. This is paragraph one. This is paragraph one. This is paragraph one. This is paragraph one. This is paragraph one.
This is paragraph two. This is paragraph two. This is paragraph two. This is paragraph two. This is paragraph two. This is paragraph two. This is paragraph two. This is paragraph two.
This is an itemized list:

section.title: Ordered Lists
section.para: This is an ordered list:

listitem.para: Another paragraph for number one item.
Another another paragraph for number one item.

section.title: Definition Lists
section.para: This is a variable list (a.k.a. Variable Lists in DocBook):

listitem.para: Term 1 definition. Term 1 definition. Term 1 definition. Term 1 definition. Term 1 definition. Term 1 definition. Term 1 definition.
Term 2 definition. Term 2 definition. Term 2 definition. Term 2 definition. Term 2 definition. Term 2 definition. Term 2 definition. Term 2 definition. Term 2 definition.

section.title: Check Box Lists
section.para: This is a check box list:

section.title: Nested Lists with Different List Types
section.para: This is a 3-level nested list:

listitem.para: This item contains a description list (or variable list in DocBook):

section.title: Lord of the Rings
section.para: My favorite scenes are (in this order)

listitem.para: Eowyn's fight with the witch king
this was already my favorite scene in the book
Peter Jackson being shot by Legolas
He makes a really funny face when it happens.

section.para: But in the end, no individual scenes matter but the film as a whole. Important actors in this film are:

listitem.para: He plays Sam, Frodo's friend. I still remember him very well from his role as Mikey Walsh in the Goonies.

section.title: About Code Reference Labels
section.para: The following is a two-line program listing. Since options "-n -r" are specified, we display the line numbers but remove the code reference labels.
In line 1 we remember the current positon. Line 2 jumps to point-min.
The following listing continues from the previous one (option "+n" is specified). Since option "-r" does not exist, code reference labels are not removed:
section.programlisting: 3: (defgroup org-export-docbook nil 4: "Options for exporting Org-mode files to DocBook." (doc) 5: :tag "Org Export DocBook" (tag) 6: :group 'org-export)
section.para: Line (doc) is the group documentation, and line (tag) is the group tag.
